desc: A place where fish and sea animals are kept for people to see.
example: We visited a large aquarium to see sharks and dolphins.

desc: A large, strong building built in the past for protection.
example: The castle was built in the 12th century.

desc: A large and important church.
example: The cathedral attracts many tourists every year.

desc: A building where Christians pray and worship.
example: They go to church every Sunday.

desc: A place where boats and ships stay safe near land.
example: Fishing boats were docked in the harbour.

desc: A place where people buy and sell things.
example: We bought fresh vegetables at the market.

desc: A statue or building made to remember an important event or person.
example: They built a monument in memory of the soldiers.

desc: A building where Muslims pray and worship.
example: The mosque was beautifully decorated for the holiday.

desc: A place where historical or interesting things are shown.
example: The museum has a collection of ancient tools.

desc: A large area of land protected for nature and wildlife.
example: We saw bears and deer in the national park.

desc: The historic part of a city, usually with old buildings.
example: We walked through the narrow streets of the old town.

desc: A building for performances of opera and classical music.
example: We bought tickets to see a concert at the opera house.

desc: A very large, beautiful house for kings or queens.
example: The queen lives in a beautiful palace.

desc: A green area with trees and space for people to relax.
example: Children were playing in the park.

desc: A place where people eat meals that are prepared and served.
example: We had dinner at an Italian restaurant.

desc: The remains of a destroyed building or structure.
example: We explored the ruins of the old castle.

desc: An area with many shops close together.
example: This shopping district has many famous brand stores.

desc: A large open area in a town, often with buildings around it.
example: The concert will be held in the main square.

desc: A figure made of stone, wood, or metal to look like a person or animal.
example: There is a statue of a famous poet in the park.

desc: A place where plays or shows are performed.
example: We watched a comedy at the theatre last night.

desc: A tall, narrow building.
example: The bell rang loudly from the tower.

desc: A place where wild animals live and can be seen safely.
example: We saw lions and giraffes in the wildlife park.

desc: A place where animals are kept for people to see.
example: The zoo has a new panda exhibit.

desc: Land with fields, forests, and farms, not in cities.
example: I enjoy walking in the peaceful countryside.

desc: A sandy or rocky area by the sea.
example: We spent all day relaxing on the beach.

desc: A short trip for fun or learning.
example: We went on a school excursion to the museum.

desc: The activity of paddling a small boat (kayak).
example: They went kayaking on the river.

desc: A fun park with rides and attractions.
example: The children were excited to visit the theme park.

desc: Going down a cliff or building with a rope.
example: We tried abseiling during our adventure holiday.

desc: A short journey on a boat.
example: They took a boat trip along the coast.

desc: Games played on a board, like chess or Monopoly.
example: We played board games all evening with friends.

desc: Small gifts or items bought to remember a place.
example: She bought some souvenirs from Paris.

desc: Lying in the sun to get warm or tan.
example: We spent the afternoon sunbathing on the beach.

desc: What are you doing?
example: Hey! What are you up to this weekend?

desc: To be doing something, often something secret or naughty.
example: The kids were getting up to something in the kitchen.

desc: How are you? / What’s happening?
example: Hey, what’s up? You look worried.

desc: How are you?
example: Hi John! How’s it going?

desc: A slang way to ask what’s happening.
example: Yo, what’s popping?

desc: To spend time relaxing with friends.
example: They love to hang out at the mall after school.

desc: To pay someone for a job or to rent something.
example: We hired a car for our trip.

desc: Worth a lot of money or important.
example: Keep your valuable items in a safe place.

desc: Classes where students do sports and physical activities.
example: P.E. is my favorite subject at school.

desc: Clothes and equipment for playing sports.
example: Don’t forget your sports kit for the match!

desc: Healthy and strong.
example: She runs every day to stay fit.

desc: Something unfortunate or disappointing.
example: Oh, that’s a shame. I really wanted to go.

desc: I don't have a preference.
example: Do you want tea or coffee? – I don’t mind.

desc: To study again or review.
example: You should revise before the exam.

desc: To organize or plan something.
example: I’ll arrange a meeting for next week.

desc: Something you do regularly or automatically.
example: Biting your nails is a bad habit.

desc: A regular way of doing things.
example: My morning routine includes a run and a shower.

desc: Something that bothers or irritates you.
example: The noise from the street is really annoying.

desc: The way someone acts.
example: Her behaviour in class was excellent.

desc: Lasting for a long time or forever.
example: He got a permanent job last year.

desc: A plan or list of things to be done.
example: Check your schedule for today’s meetings.

desc: To take something for a short time with permission.
example: Can I borrow your pen for a moment?

desc: To reach a place.
example: The train will arrive at 6 PM.

desc: To do something quickly.
example: Hurry up or we’ll be late!

desc: To be the property of someone or something.
example: This book belongs to my sister.

desc: To like one thing more than another.
example: I prefer tea to coffee.

desc: To stop someone while they are speaking or doing something.
example: Please don’t interrupt me while I’m speaking.

desc: To want to do something or feel like doing something.
example: Do you fancy going to the cinema tonight?

desc: A prediction of future weather or events.
example: The weather forecast says it will rain tomorrow.

desc: Very tired.
example: After a long day at work, I felt exhausted.

desc: A string instrument played with a bow.
example: She plays the violin in the school orchestra.

desc: A person who manages financial records and accounts.
example: My uncle works as an accountant in a big company.

desc: An idea or answer you say without being sure.
example: I don’t know the answer – it’s just a guess.

desc: The activity of exploring caves.
example: Caving can be dangerous without proper equipment.

desc: Feeling anxious or worried.
example: She was nervous before her interview.

desc: Extending far down or inward.
example: The lake is very deep in the middle.

desc: Very interesting or exciting.
example: Space is a fascinating subject to study.

desc: To go and look for new places or things.
example: They love to explore new cities when they travel.

desc: To find something for the first time.
example: Scientists discovered a new species of fish.

desc: A journey or trip, usually for a specific purpose.
example: They went on an expedition to the Arctic.

desc: To jump or plunge into water.
example: He took a dive into the swimming pool.

desc: Soft, wet earth.
example: The children played in the mud after the rain.

desc: To give something to someone for a short time.
example: Can you lend me a pencil?

desc: A document that gives you a discount or free item.
example: I have a voucher for a free meal at the café.
